chapter.title: Figures, Diagrams, Screen Shots, and In-Line Graphics

section.title: Overview
section.para: Graphics, such as a diagram or a screen shot of a user interface, make a document more readable. Often, they also help clarify abstract concepts.

In the CeltiXfire(CXF) documentation figures, diagrams, and screen shots contain images stored in external files. They are denoted using one of two elements: figure or screenshot. The figure element is used to denote a figure or a diagram. The screen element is used to denote a screen shot.

section.title: Figures and Diagrams
section.para: Figures and diagrams are marked up the same way in the CXF documentation. They are both placed in a figure element. The figure element is a container for the caption and data that make up the figure or diagram.

The caption is specified by a title element. The title element is the first child element of the figure element. The contents of the title element is the caption used for the figure. It is also the default text used when you cross reference the figure.

The image data is specified in a mediaobject element. The mediaobject element is a wrapper for an imageobject element. The imageobject element is also a wrapper element. The imageobject element wraps an imagedata element that specifies the name of the file containing the image.
The imagedata element has no content. All of the information is specified using three attributes:

row.entry: Specifies how the image is aligned on the page. Valid values are left, right, and center.
Specifies the location of the file containing the image.
Specifies the type of data used to specifiy the image. Valid values are GIF, JPG, and PNG.

section.title: In-Line Graphics
section.para: Graphical elements that need to be placed in-line with the text of a paragraph are marked up using the inlinemediaobject element. Like the mediaobject element, the inlinemediaobject element is a wrapper for an imageobject element. shows the mark-up for an in-line graphic.

section.title: Adding Alternate Text
section.para: Images on the Web should all have alternative text, so when using a graphic in CeltiXfire documentation you will need to add mark-up to specify the alternate text.

To put alternative text with a graphic you add a textobject element after the imageobject element as shown in . The textobject element has a single phrase child element. The value of the phrase element is the alternative text used when the documentation is generated to HTML.
